bioghist.p: Gordon Bowles (1904-1991), the son of Quaker missionaries, was born in Japan, and lived there until he graduated from high school. He attended Earlham College where he studied zoology, after which he took graduate courses in anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania for one year before transferring to Harvard. During his time in Penn, he made the acquaintance of Horace Jayne, the director of the University Museum. Jayne later told Bowles about the expedition to China being planned by Brooke Dolan. Having received a scholarship from the Harvard-Yenching Institute for Chinese Studies, Gordon was able to join the expedition.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence and photocopies of maps and expedition journals of Gordon T. Bowles. The letters include reports to Horace Jayne and Chien Tien Ho (of Academia Sinica), and discussion of the logistics of shipping the specimens collected on the expedition back to the United States. There are also inventories of the ethnological specimens collected in Tibet and items presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Natural History in Nanking. The journals (only volumes three and four are present) are photocopies of Gordon's notebooks kept during the trip.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
